Dialogue: They're shitty.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Good morning, gentlemen. Welcome to another season of Indians' baseball.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: I know that it may not seem the same without Donald here this year, but I promise you by the end of the season this team will have made history.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: "the ex-showgirl wife of Donald Phelps has no business being the owner of a major league baseball team."

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Obviously, Donald didn't feel that way or he wouldn't have left the team to me. And I was more than showgirl. I was a dancer. Now, I know some of you have doubts about my ability to run this franchise. God help you if I ever find out about it.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Spring training begins in two weeks.  Here's the list of people we'll be inviting to camp this year.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: I could sit here and tell you what a great year we're gonna have, but the facts are we lost the two best players we had to free agency. We haven't won a pennant in 30 years. We haven't even finished in the first division for 15. Obviously it's time to make some changes. What do ya think?

Speaker: simmons
Dialogue: I never heard of half these guys. And the ones I do know are way past their prime.

Speaker: donovan
Dialogue: Most of these guys never had a prime.

Speaker: butler
Dialogue: This guy here is dead.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Cross him off then.

Speaker: butler
Dialogue: Let's not be hasty.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: It's time to shake things up, Charlie. Clear the board and start over.

Speaker: donovan
Dialogue: Well, it's not the best material I've ever had to work with, but I'll do my best to see we move up a notch this year.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: I know you will, Charlie. That's why I'm movin' you up to General Manager. Congratulations.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Well, that should do it for today. Thank you, gentlemen. Let's get to work.

Speaker: matthews
Dialogue: One minute, 58 seconds.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Come on in, Charlie. Have a seat.

Speaker: donovan
Dialogue: I'm glad you called me in. I'm still unclear on a couple things

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Oh, really? Like what?

Speaker: donovan
Dialogue: Well, if I'm the G.M., who's gonna be the Manager?

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: I was thinking of Lou Brown.

Speaker: donovan
Dialogue: Lou Brown?

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: He's managed the Toledo Mud Hens of the International League for the last 30 years.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: I think he'll fit right in with our team concept.

Speaker: donovan
Dialogue: What exactly is our team concept?

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: That's what I wanted to talk to you about. I want to put together a team that will help us relocate to Miami.

Speaker: donovan
Dialogue: What do you mean?  Some of these guys are furniture movers?

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: I'm serious about this, Charlie. It's no secret I've never liked Cleveland much. The weather's lousy, downtown is a pit, the stadium's falling apart, and we can't draw dick. Another couple of years of this and I'm gonna have to start feeding Cha-Cha dog food.

Speaker: donovan
Dialogue: Mrs. Phelps, you can't just up and move a team on a whim...

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: It's hardly a whim. Miami's offered to build us a new stadium -- 62,000 capacity, 45 V.I.P. boxes, and no rent for the first million at the gate. Plus a 12 million dollar media guarantee; 45 percent of the concession gross, all of the parking and they pick up the stadium operations costs. No other franchise in baseball can match that deal.

Speaker: donovan
Dialogue: Even so, the League'll never let us leave Cleveland. We got a lease with the city.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: The lease says we have the right to move if our attendance falls below 800,000 for the year.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: If we play bad enough, we should be able to come in under that.

Speaker: donovan
Dialogue: What are you saying? You want us to lose?

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: No, we've been losing. What I want us to do is finish dead last.

Speaker: donovan
Dialogue: Mister Phelps would never have approved of this.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: He knew it had to be done. He just didn't have the courage to do it.  If this team lives up to its potential, we could have the worst record in all baseball.

Dialogue: Yeh.

Dialogue: I figure you got a 30% chance to survive this at bat.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: Wild thing, You make my heart sing, You walk everything.

Speaker: pepper
Dialogue: Okay kid. I think we got 'em scared enough now. Time to get a few of 'em out.

Speaker: pepper
Dialogue: Just relax, and keep the arm up on top. Gotta throw strikes. No place at the inn for this guy.

Speaker: haywood
Dialogue: Hey, Taylor, what you doin' back up here?

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Couldn't cut it in the Mexican League.

Speaker: vaughn
Dialogue: Oh, shit...

Speaker: pepper
Dialogue: Looked like a strike anyway. You want me to go get him?

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: No, let's see how he reacts.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Interesting.

Speaker: pepper
Dialogue: At least he hit what he was aimin' at.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: I think you can go get him now.

Speaker: pepper
Dialogue: C'mon, kid. As soon as Coleman gets up, he's gonna be lookin' for you.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: So, a tough start for the Erie warriors, as they drop a heartbreaker to the Yankees, nine to nothing. The Post Game Show was brought to you by...  Christ. I can't find it. The hell with it. This is Harry Doyle saying good night, everybody, and Happy Hunting.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: We're off to a good start, gentlemen. Let's keep it up.

Speaker: vaughn
Dialogue: God, I was horse shit tonight.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Only thing you got to be sorry about was hittin' Coleman.

Speaker: vaughn
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: If you wanted to send a message, it shoulda been to Haywood. He hit the damn homer. Coleman was just picking his nose in the on-deck circle.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Forget the other stuff. It coulda happened to anybody. Besides, Haywood didn't hit it that good. That ball wouldn't have been out of a lotta parks.

Speaker: vaughn
Dialogue: Oh yeh, name one.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Yellowstone.

Speaker: vaughn
Dialogue: Shit...

Speaker: lynn
Dialogue: Jake, you shouldn't have come here.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: I was wonderin' why you'd give an old friend a bum phone number.

Speaker: lynn
Dialogue: Let's talk in my office, okay?

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: I don't wanna talk in your office.

Speaker: lynn
Dialogue: I told you I don't think it's a good idea for us to see each other.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Why not?

Speaker: lynn
Dialogue: We don't have anything in common. Sometimes I wonder if we ever did.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: What are you talkin' about? We were both athletes, world class, hot for each other. What more can you have in common?

Speaker: lynn
Dialogue: I stopped bein' an athlete three years ago. Books are my life now.

Speaker: lynn
Dialogue: Don't you dare laugh, Jake. In two years I've put together one of the best special collections departments in the country.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: So what is it? You're still sore I never read Moby Dick?

Speaker: lynn
Dialogue: You never read anything I asked you to.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Not like what's-his-name at the restaurant?

Speaker: lynn
Dialogue: His name is Tom, and keep your voice down.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: What do ya see in this guy?

Speaker: lynn
Dialogue: He's stable. He's intelligent... and I've never found him in bed with a stewardess.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: That's 'cause no stewardess would have him. Wouldn't you rather be with somebody who's in demand?

Speaker: lynn
Dialogue: Just like always, you don't take anything seriously. Everything's a joke to you.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: C'mon, Lynn, for Christ sake, I'm just tryin' to loosen things up a little. I'm gettin' frostbite here.

Speaker: lynn
Dialogue: Tom and I are getting married in the fall.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: What? That's crazy, Lynn. I got plans for us.

Speaker: lynn
Dialogue: What plans?

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: I was gonna play another a year or two, then we go to Hawaii, and have a couple kids who grow up to be Olympic champions.

Speaker: lynn
Dialogue: How can you think stuff like that? I haven't seen you in two years. You never even wrote me a letter.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: I'm sorry, Lynn, but I wasn't exactly proud of my situation. C'mon, you didn't think about me at all since I been gone?

Speaker: lynn
Dialogue: Not so loud, Jake.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Remember the three nights we spent on the beach in Vera Cruz? You have nights like that with Mr. Briefcase?

Speaker: lynn
Dialogue: What about the night you had in Detroit with Miss Dairy Queen?

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: What was I supposed to do? She bet me fifty bucks she had a better body than you. I had to defend your honor.

Speaker: lynn
Dialogue: I have a much better body than she does.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: She's right. Take it from me, she really does. I mean Miss Dairy Queen has quantity, I give her that, but the, ah, quality just isn't there.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: How many think Lynn oughta give me another shot?

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: The ayes have it.

Speaker: lynn
Dialogue: You haven't changed at all, have you?

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: I'm afraid I have or I wouldn't be here. C'mon, Lynn, I don't wanna do time for things that happened years ago.

Speaker: lynn
Dialogue: I'm sorry, Jake. You'll always be the little boy who wouldn't grow up.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Lynn, wait...

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: A quarter of the season's gone, we're 15 and 24, seven games out of first. Our attendance is just below 180,000. That's bad, but not bad enough.

Speaker: donovan
Dialogue: Projected over the whole season, we stand to wind up 36 games under .500 and 28 out of first. That should be bad enough for anybody.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: We finished 24 out last year and still drew 890,000. When school's out for the summer, attendance is liable to rise. Plus, this team is showing signs of improvement. I didn't think we'd win 15 games all year. Any ideas?

Speaker: donovan
Dialogue: On how we can get worse?  How about a series of fines for good play? Maybe a $30,000 bonus to the guy chosen Least Valuable Player.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: This is no laughing matter, Donovan.  I think maybe the problem is we're coddling these guys too much.

Speaker: hayes
Dialogue: What's with this? We never leave from this terminal.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Maybe the other one's jammed up.

Speaker: hayes
Dialogue: Which one is ours?

Speaker: gateman
Dialogue: That one.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: What is this, Lou?

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Front office says it's an economy measure, 'cause we're not drawin' good.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Well, they certainly have spared every expense.

Speaker: harris
Dialogue: Oh, so now you come around.  He's not fooled.

Speaker: hayes
Dialogue: Call the stewardess, Vaughn. I need one of those bags.

Speaker: vaughn
Dialogue: There aren't any stewardesses.

Speaker: hayes
Dialogue: I wonder if there's any pilots.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Two down, top of the ninth. Last chance for the red and blue.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: So, the Sons of Geronimo, still suffering a bit from propeller lag, are nipped by the Tigers tonight, 7 to 0. The only excitement for the tribe provided by Rick Vaughn who set an American League record by throwing four wild pitches in one inning. Congratulations, Rick. For the Tigers, 5 runs, 9 hits, and no errors. For the Indians, one run, and let's see, one hit.  Is that all we got, one fucking hit?

Speaker: stat man
Dialogue: You can't say "fuckin'" on the air.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Don't worry about it. Nobody's listening anyway.

Speaker: harris
Dialogue: Who you got lined up tonight?

Speaker: dorn
Dialogue: Where are we? Kansas City, right? Gotta be Arlene

Speaker: harris
Dialogue: You call her?

Speaker: dorn
Dialogue: Don't have to. She knows when I'm in town.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: I'm about ready to turn in. I've anesthetized my knees enough.

Speaker: guy
Dialogue: Excuse me, Mr. Vaughn, can I have your autograph?

Speaker: vaughn
Dialogue: Ah... yeh... sure.  My first autograph. I couldn't give these away a couple weeks ago.

Speaker: guy
Dialogue: I saw your record on the news. You made their Hall of Shame. Congratulations.

Speaker: vaughn
Dialogue: Thanks.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: You're a celebrity now, Vaughn.

Speaker: vaughn
Dialogue: I thought you had to do somethin' good to be a celebrity.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Not if you do it colorfully.

Speaker: dorn
Dialogue: What'd I tell ya.

Speaker: arlene
Dialogue: Hi, Rodger. This is Vicki and Rene.

Speaker: dorn
Dialogue: Hi, doll. This is Steve Harris.

Speaker: arlene
Dialogue: Where's your buddy Gant?

Speaker: dorn
Dialogue: They cut him to make room for bristle boy over there.

Speaker: arlene
Dialogue: Is that Vaughn, the guy they call Wild Thing?

Speaker: dorn
Dialogue: Yeh.

Speaker: arlene
Dialogue: He's kinda cute. They say he could be a big star.

Speaker: dorn
Dialogue: What are you talkin' about? He couldn't find the plate if it was magnetized. He won't last the year.

Speaker: arlene
Dialogue: He struck out five in a row before the wild pitches.  Maybe I'll check him out.

Speaker: dorn
Dialogue: Wait a minute, you're with me.

Speaker: arlene
Dialogue: I don't remember you makin' any date.

Speaker: dorn
Dialogue: Since when do I have to make a date? Who's been showin' you this town the last three years?

Speaker: arlene
Dialogue: Ancient history, Rodger. I gotta look out for myself now. I don't have to be a slave to no .235 hitter.

Speaker: arlene
Dialogue: Wild Thing, you make my heart sing.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Guess we're over with, eh, Dorn?

Speaker: dorn
Dialogue: Speak for yourself, Taylor. I got a couple good years left.

Speaker: hayes
Dialogue: "Moby Dick?" What is that?

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: It's one of the masterpieces of American literature, that's all.

Speaker: hayes
Dialogue: Lynn put you on to this?

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Long time ago.

Speaker: hayes
Dialogue: Well, we're goin' to a club tonight. You wanna come along?

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: No, I got some more reading to do.

Speaker: hayes
Dialogue: What, you got a test or somethin'? Why don't you just go over and see her? Maybe she'll let you slide on a couple of these.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: I might if I knew where she lives.

Speaker: hayes
Dialogue: Easy. Tail her home from the library.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: You mean sit in a car and wait for her to come out? That's kinda juvenile, don't you think?

Speaker: hayes
Dialogue: Yeh.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Look, Lynn, I'm sorry I followed you home but I wanna...

Speaker: lynn
Dialogue: This isn't my place...

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Whose place is it?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Who's there, love?  I remember you from the restaurant. Lynn's told me a lot about you. Why don't you come in for a while?

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Nah, that's o.k., I got some things to do...

Speaker: lynn
Dialogue: Yeh, he's gotta be goin'...

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: No, really, come on in for a drink.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Excuse me, everybody, this is Jake Taylor.  Jake, Arthur and Claire Holloway Brent and Janice Bowden. Jake is a professional baseball player.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: So, Jake, what brings you here this evening?

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: I, ah, just had a couple books I wanted to discuss with Lynn. I thought this was her place.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Well, it soon will be.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Yeh, I heard you guys were engaged. Congratulations.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Thank you. What can I get you to drink?

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Beer'll be fine.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: What team do you play for, Jake?

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: The Indians.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Here in Cleveland? I didn't know they still had a team.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Yeh, we have uniforms and everything. It's really great.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: They're last right now, but hopefully moving up, eh, Jake?

Speaker: janice
Dialogue: I'm told that baseball players make very good salaries these days.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: That depends on how good they are, I guess.

Speaker: janice
Dialogue: How good are you?

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: I make the League minimum.

Speaker: lynn
Dialogue: He was one of the best in baseball until he had problems with his knees.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: What are you going to do when your career ends? I mean you can't play baseball forever, can you?

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Somethin'll come up.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Will it?

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: I don't know, I was thinkin' of goin' to Hawaii, and having a couple of kids who grow up to be Olympic champions.

Speaker: jack
Dialogue: Oh really. In what event?

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Swimming. Maybe the two hundred meter Individual Medley. I figure it oughta be big by then.

Speaker: brent
Dialogue: You got the girl picked out?

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: I did, but I wasn't smart enough to hold on to her.

Speaker: brent
Dialogue: You used to be an athlete, didn't you, Lynn?

Speaker: lynn
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: brent
Dialogue: What did you do?

Speaker: lynn
Dialogue: Two Hundred Individual medley.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Alternate on the '80 Olympic Team.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Well, I gotta be goin'. Nice to have met you all.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Let me walk you out.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Thanks for the beer.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Don't mention it.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: I'll let you know if I land a good job. I know you're concerned about it.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Yeh, well, I just wanted Lynn to know what she would've had ahead of her.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Stay away from her.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Suck my dick.

Speaker: pepper
Dialogue: Lou wants to see you down at the office, Rick.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: C'mon in, Rick.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Rick, I'm not gonna beat around the bush here. You got a great arm, one of the best I've ever seen, but your control hasn't come around like we hoped it would.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Now, there are a lotta pitchers that started out wild and, after workin' it out in the minors, for a while, went on to great careers.  Take Sandy Koufax there...

Speaker: vaughn
Dialogue: What about Koufax?

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Never mind Koufax.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Read these letters, starting at the top.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Can't read it, can you?

Speaker: vaughn
Dialogue: You gonna send me to the minors?

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Nope.

Speaker: vaughn
Dialogue: These things make me look ridiculous.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Drop in the bucket, Vaughn.

Speaker: vaughn
Dialogue: What's that for?

Speaker: cerrano
Dialogue: Gin and cigarettes not enough for Jo- Buu. I still can no hit curva ball for sheet. I hafta make a sacrifice to him.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Sacrifice? You mean like something living?

Speaker: cerrano
Dialogue: Si. I kill unborn children.

Speaker: harris
Dialogue: Not while I'm here you're not. That's murder.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: All right, let's hit the field.

Speaker: harris
Dialogue: Here's looking at ya, Jo-Buu.

Speaker: pepper
Dialogue: You want me to go get him?

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: No, he's come this far. Let's see if he can finish it.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Vaughn in a little trouble here, but I'll tell ya, these Cleveland fans are great. Listen to them get behind Vaughn.

Speaker: bobby
Dialogue: We need some defense here. Maybe we oughta do a wave.

Speaker: johnny
Dialogue: C'mon, Indians don't do waves. Let's keep this thing pure.

Speaker: vic
Dialogue: What harm could it do?

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Forget the runners, Ricky, get this guy at the plate.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: High ball two, and the crowd doesn't like that call one bit.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Okay, let's get nasty here, Rick. You know he's lookin' for this pitch. Gotta come up with somethin' studly.

Speaker: vaughn
Dialogue: Fuckin' Dorn. Game shoulda been over by now. Dorn coulda had that ball. He tanked it on purpose.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: This isn't the California Penal League, Vaughn. We're professionals here. We don't tank a play for personal reasons, so cut the crybaby shit. You've pitched a helluva game. You wanna finish it, don't ya?

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Can you give me a strike on this pitch?

Speaker: vaughn
Dialogue: Yeh, but I don't know if there'll be much on it. My arm feels like jello.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Just make sure it's over the plate. I want him to swing.

Speaker: vaughn
Dialogue: The last time I did that, the guy hit one that hasn't landed yet.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Don't worry, I'll take care of it.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: By the way, I been meaning to ask you. Why'd you steal that car?

Speaker: vaughn
Dialogue: I was bored.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Next time you might think about takin' in a movie or somethin'.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Helluva situation we got goin' here, huh, Rexman? Two on, two out, you're down by a run in the ninth. You got a chance to be a hero on national television, so whatever you do, don't blow it. They'll be callin' you a gutless choke artist all over America.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: You're a free agent at the end of the year. Not much demand for gutless choke artists. What are you hittin' now? .230? .240?

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Hey, nice average. Uh oh, on second thought, that still means you got a seven outta ten chance of goin' in the dumper.

Speaker: rexman
Dialogue: Shut up, will ya, Taylor?

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Hey, I can understand not wantin' to talk about baseball when your nuts are in a vice like this.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: By the way, I saw your wife at the Capri Lounge last night. Hell of a dancer. You must be very proud.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: But that guy she was with... I mean I'm sure he's a close personal friend of yours and all, but tell me...

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: ...Why was he wearing her panties on his head?

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Uh oh, Rexie, I don't think that one's got the distance. Maybe if the wind comes up.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: It's startin' to come together, Pepper. It's startin' to come together.

Speaker: suzanne
Dialogue: Oh hi, Jake, how are you?

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Fine, Suzanne, can I have a quick word with Rodger?

Speaker: suzanne
Dialogue: Sure, c'mon in, he's in the den. I'll get some coffee.

Speaker: dorn
Dialogue: Hey, Jake, old boy, what brings you out here?

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: I just wanta tell ya somethin', but I didn't want to do it in front of the whole team.

Speaker: dorn
Dialogue: Sure, go ahead.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: ...if I ever see you tank another play like you did tonight, I'll cut off your nuts and stuff 'em down your fuckin' throat.

Speaker: suzanne
Dialogue: Coffee anybody?

Speaker: hayes
Dialogue: Why the hell are we havin' practice during the All-Star break?

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: I heard the Big Lady upstairs ordered it.

Speaker: vaughn
Dialogue: It's hotter than shit in here. What happened to the air conditioning?

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Oh man, this old body can use a soak.

Speaker: dorn
Dialogue: Forget it. It's not workin' again.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Damn it, I thought they were gonna replace this thing.

Speaker: harris
Dialogue: Hey, there's no hot water in here.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: She's at it again. I've had it with this nickel and dime stuff.  I'm gonna get the Bitch on the phone.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: You wanted to see the Bitch?

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Yeh.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Don't you think you oughta cover yourself with a towel first, Mr. Brown?

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: There aren't any towels, and I'm too old to be diving under benches.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Well, I can take it if you can.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: What happened to the new whirlpool we were supposed to get?

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Revenue problems have forced us to cut back on equipment. We'll simply have to fix the old one.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: You fixed it six times already. And now there's no hot water in the showers.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: The pipes in this building are old and rusted. We're replacing them, but it's a long, expensive process.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: How am I supposed to keep my players healthy with cold water and no therapy equipment?

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Your players will just have to get a little tougher. What are they, a bunch of pansies?

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Over 162 games even tough guys get sprains, sore arms, muscle pulls...

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: It's only temporary. Besides, these guys weren't playing that good when the equipment was workin'. If I could get anybody to come and watch this team, none of this would be necessary. You oughta be grateful I can still pay your salaries.

Speaker: farmer
Dialogue: In case you haven't noticed, and judging by attendance, you haven't, the Indians, that thought-to-be hopeless collection of has-been's and never-will-be's is actually approaching the .500 mark, and with it, semi-respectability. Nothing to write home about, to be sure, but at least we don't have to cover our eyes.

Speaker: vic
Dialogue: Ya know, they could be a lot worse.

Speaker: business executive
Dialogue: Ya know, I may have underestimated this team a bit.

Speaker: longshoreman
Dialogue: Ya know, these guys aren't so fuckin' bad.

Speaker: groundskeeper
Dialogue: They're still shitty.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Ah shit, here comes Lou. Gimme a break, Mel. I gotta get outta here.

Speaker: wingo
Dialogue: All right, kick some dirt on me. The Commissioner'll buy that.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Right. Good idea.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Hey, don't you go anywhere. I wanna have a few words with you.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: What are we arguin' about here?

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Fucker called that a ball.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: You mean the one that was a foot outside?

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Yeh.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: You still got that great kick. Just like the first time I ever saw you.

Speaker: lynn
Dialogue: You follow me here too?

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Yeh, what did you want to see me about?

Speaker: lynn
Dialogue: What do you mean?

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: You wouldn't have been at the game if you didn't want to see me about something.

Speaker: lynn
Dialogue: I just wanted to see you play.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: How was I?

Speaker: lynn
Dialogue: You looked good, but you oughta open your stance a little. They're pitching you inside.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: I'll try that. You wanna have some dinner?

Speaker: lynn
Dialogue: Sorry, I already ate.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Right. I forgot your life is different now.

Speaker: lynn
Dialogue: Thanks for the race.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Anytime.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Whose place are we at this time?

Speaker: lynn
Dialogue: Mine. You follow me again?

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Yeh. When I saw you at the game, I figured you wanted to see me about something.

Speaker: lynn
Dialogue: I just wanted to see you play.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: How was I?

Speaker: lynn
Dialogue: You looked good, but you oughta open your stance a little. They're pitchin' you inside.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: I'll try that.

Speaker: lynn
Dialogue: I think I oughta tell you that I'm moving in with Tom.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Goin' uptown, huh?

Speaker: lynn
Dialogue: I'm not goin' uptown, I just want to lead a regular life. You know, like an adult maybe. With a house and a garden and normal hours.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: You think I can't lead a regular life?

Speaker: lynn
Dialogue: You like the life you've had, Jake. You like hangin' out with the boys, livin' in hotels, eatin' dinner at midnight, having girls send you their underwear in the mail. Remember the surprise party I threw for you when you made the All-Star team? You never showed up, but the doorbell rang once and we all got quiet and hid behind the furniture. It was a guy to serve you with a paternity suit.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: That was a hoax. The girl was just trying to get some publicity.

Speaker: lynn
Dialogue: Yes, but you had obviously been with her. And it happened in front of all our friends.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: I was drownin', Lynn. The endorsements were dryin' up, my knees were goin', they were talkin' about sendin' me down. I was just trying to hold on to somethin', prove to myself I was still an All-Star. I don't care about that anymore. I know I don't have much time left in baseball. I'm just a guy trying to put his life back together. Thinkin' about you was the only thing that kept me goin' in Mexico.

Speaker: lynn
Dialogue: I've come back to you too many times, Jake. I can't afford to believe you anymore.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: I guess this is our last hurrah then.

Speaker: lynn
Dialogue: I guess so. Did you really read "Moby Dick?"

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Cover to cover.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: When's the wedding?

Speaker: lynn
Dialogue: October third.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Your mom and dad like this guy?

Speaker: lynn
Dialogue: You're still their favorite.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Gonna be a big wedding?

Speaker: lynn
Dialogue: Tom doesn't like big weddings. You coulda read Plot Outlines of 101 Great Novels.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Where?

Speaker: lynn
Dialogue: At any library.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: I mean the wedding.

Speaker: lynn
Dialogue: All Saints on Euclid.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Nice church.

Speaker: lynn
Dialogue: Yeh. Who saved Ishmael at the end?

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Nobody. It was Queequeg's coffin. Am I invited?

Speaker: lynn
Dialogue: Where?

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: To the wedding.

Speaker: lynn
Dialogue: If you want. Maybe you really did read it.

Speaker: lynn
Dialogue: This doesn't change anything, you know. We were always good at this.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Lynn?

Speaker: lynn
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: The zipper on your skirt is stuck.

Speaker: lynn
Dialogue: Use your imagination.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Well, my worst fears have been confirmed. We're 60 and 60, nine games out of first, and only two out of the first division. Who do those guys think they are?

Speaker: donovan
Dialogue: Maybe you just have to accept the fact that they're not as bad as you'd hoped.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: I don't have to accept anything. Our attendance is only beginning to rise. If we can force a losing streak for a week or two, we can still turn this thing around. The fans are used to losers here. At the first sign of a slump they'll give up on this team.

Speaker: donovan
Dialogue: What's left to do? You've taken away everything you can.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Not everything.

Speaker: temple
Dialogue: Memo says we'll only be usin' this for short trips.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Good thing we don't play anybody in Europe.

Speaker: hayes
Dialogue: Can I borrow one of those, man? They don't have any magazines on this bus.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Sure, go ahead. I think my reading days are over.

Speaker: hayes
Dialogue: Macbeth. This a good one?

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: These are all Hall of Famers.

Speaker: hayes
Dialogue: I'll trade you Song of Hiawatha for The Deerslayer.

Speaker: dorn
Dialogue: Naw, I'm not into Song of Hiawatha.

Speaker: hayes
Dialogue: All right then, how about Crime and Punishment?

Speaker: dorn
Dialogue: Yeh, that sounds pretty good. That's a detective story, right?

Speaker: hayes
Dialogue: Yeh.

Speaker: driver
Dialogue: This is it. The Sheffield Arms.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: I don't know if we can survive any more of these economy measures.

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: Hey, jailbird!

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: C'mon, Rick baby, settle down.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: What's the problem, Rick? You're throwin' basketballs up there. That guy in the dugout botherin' you?

Speaker: vaughn
Dialogue: Naw, I'm all right.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Forget him. Worry about the guys carryin' bats. C'mon, Ricky, let's get nasty.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: I thought now that Vaughn had some control, he was ready for the Yankees.

Speaker: pepper
Dialogue: Not quite yet.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Well, the Indians made a gallant comeback today, but fell one run short as the Yankees held on for a 6- 5 victory, although they didn't do squat after the first inning. Anyway, if the bus makes it here from the hotel we'll be on at 7:30 tomorrow night. Till then, this is Harry Doyle, saying so long, everybody, and Happy Hunting.

Speaker: donovan
Dialogue: Mind if I join you?

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Donovan. Hell no. What are you doin' here?

Speaker: donovan
Dialogue: Just wanted to get out on the road. You damn near pulled one out today.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Someday we'll figure out how to beat those guys.

Speaker: donovan
Dialogue: Ya know, you've done a helluva job this year.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Sixty and sixty-one is hardly a helluva job.

Speaker: donovan
Dialogue: With this club it is.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Ya know, when I first got to camp I figured this team had no chance. I was just hopin' we'd win enough that I could stay on and really start to build something here. But there's a lotta talent on this club, Charlie. The veterans are starting to play back to form and the rookies are developing faster than I thought. There's two or three potential all- stars in there. I think we're a first division team right now.

Speaker: donovan
Dialogue: You really believe that, don't you?

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: I know it. All we need is something to bring it all together.

Speaker: donovan
Dialogue: Rachel Phelps would never allow that.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: What do you mean?

Speaker: donovan
Dialogue: She doesn't want you in the first division. She doesn't even want you in Cleveland.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: I got somethin' I think you oughta know about. I wouldn't have known about it myself if Charlie Donovan hadn't told me, although I shoulda guessed it from everything that's happened. It seems that Mrs. Phelps doesn't think too highly of our worth.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: She put this team together because she thought we'd be bad enough to finish dead last, knockin' attendance down to the point where she could move the team to Miami.  And get rid of all of us for better personnel.

Speaker: dorn
Dialogue: Even me?

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Even you, Dorn.

Speaker: hayes
Dialogue: In other words, Phelps thinks we're all dinks. That we don't belong in the big leagues.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: That's about it.

Speaker: harris
Dialogue: What if we don't finish last?

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: She'll replace you with somebody who will. After this season, you'll all be sent back to the minors or given your outright release.  So, all we're gonna get is this one year.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: I don't know about the rest of you, but I've been playin' baseball since I was five years old. I've had some good years and some years to forget. I've burned out my knees... I don't think I have three fingers that work right... I've lost most of the money I made and baseball has messed up my personal life from time to time. But I know one thing... I can still play this game a little. And I'd like to know who in this room thinks they're the kinda bum Mrs. Phelps is lookin' for?

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Well, then, I guess there's only one thing to do.

Speaker: dorn
Dialogue: What's that?

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Win the whole fuckin' thing.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: I figure it's gonna take 32 more victories to win this thing. Every time we win, we peel a square.

Speaker: farmer
Dialogue: You remember bra burning in the '70's, well, the newest thing in Cleveland is doormat burning as Indian fans are standing up and saying "We won't be stepped on anymore".

Speaker: team
Dialogue: Hello, do you know us?

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: We're a Major League baseball team, but since we haven't won a pennant in thirty years, nobody recognizes us, not even in our own hometown.

Speaker: vaughn
Dialogue: That's why we carry the American Express card. No matter how far out of first we are, it keeps us from getting shut out at our favorite hotels and restaurants.

Speaker: cerrano
Dialogue: So if you're looking for some big league clout, apply for the little green home run hitter.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Look what it's done for us. People still don't recognize us, but...  ...we're in the first division now.

Speaker: hayes
Dialogue: The American Express card. Don't steal home without it.

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: We interrupt this program to bring you the following special bulletin.

Speaker: farmer
Dialogue: Good evening, everybody. The incredible has happened. The Indians have finished the regular season in a first place tie with the New York Yankees on the strength of a 4-2 win over the Tigers in Detroit today. There will be a one-game playoff here in Cleveland the day after tomorrow to decide the Eastern Division Championship, the Indians having won the coin flip held just moments ago in the American League office. We'll have further details on the news at 11, but for now, get your tomahawks ready, Cleveland.

Speaker: hayes
Dialogue: Hey, not bad for a has-been and a never-will-be.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: We haven't won anything yet. We still got one more to go.

Speaker: dorn
Dialogue: Hey, Taylor, there's a coupla drop- dead Annies outside. One of 'em says she used to know you pretty good. Brunette, great rack...

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Darla.

Speaker: dorn
Dialogue: Yeh. What doya say we chat 'em up?

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: I don't know...

Speaker: dorn
Dialogue: C'mon, you're not gonna keep moonin' over that library chick, are you? Forget her, she's gone.

Speaker: charles
Dialogue: The Indians are spending the night in Detroit and will bus back to Cleveland in the morning. We're going to go back now to Ross Farmer who's standing by at the Hotel Stanley where the Indians are staying in Detroit. Ross?

Speaker: farmer
Dialogue: Thank you, Hal. As you can see, the Indians are in high spirits tonight, looking forward to their showdown with the Yankees. Who will start that game is still a matter of some conjecture.

Speaker: darla
Dialogue: You still got that black Corvette? The one that the sound system took up the whole trunk?

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: No, I had to sell it.

Speaker: darla
Dialogue: I thought they gave them to ya.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Not after your knees go bad.

Speaker: darla
Dialogue: That's all right, you'll be gettin' a new one now.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Darla, I don't think I can do this.

Speaker: darla
Dialogue: What do you mean? We did this between innings once.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: I guess I'm just not that guy anymore.

Speaker: darla
Dialogue: Happens to the best of them sooner or later. What's her name?

Speaker: darla
Dialogue: So long, Jake. Too bad. I was gonna devote a whole chapter to you in my book.

Speaker: lynn
Dialogue: Excuse me. I was in town for a conference and thought I'd drop by, but I can see you're busy...

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Lynn, wait...

Speaker: vaughn
Dialogue: You wanted to see me?

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Yeh, Rick. I just wanted to tell you that I'm startin' Harris tomorrow against the Yankees, even though it's your turn in the rotation.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: He's got more experience and a little better record against the Yankees.

Speaker: vaughn
Dialogue: Yeh, sure. Whatever's best for the team.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Don't read anything into it, Rick. You're one of the guys that got us here.

Speaker: vaughn
Dialogue: Yeh, okay.

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: You mind if I join you?

Speaker: vaughn
Dialogue: I don't think I'd be very good company tonight.

Speaker: suzanne
Dialogue: Why not?

Speaker: vaughn
Dialogue: Nothin'. Job problem.

Speaker: vaughn
Dialogue: I'm, ah, a ball player.

Speaker: suzanne
Dialogue: I know, but that's not why I came over. I don't chase ball players.

Speaker: vaughn
Dialogue: Why did you come over then?

Speaker: suzanne
Dialogue: Because you're the sexiest man I've ever laid eyes on, and you look like you could use a... friend.

Speaker: vaughn
Dialogue: Where you goin'?

Speaker: suzanne
Dialogue: I've gotta get home.

Speaker: vaughn
Dialogue: I didn't even get your name.

Speaker: suzanne
Dialogue: Suzanne. Suzanne Dorn

Speaker: vaughn
Dialogue: Suzanne Dorn?

Speaker: suzanne
Dialogue: Mrs. Suzanne Dorn.  So long. You're a great kid.

Speaker: suzanne
Dialogue: Hello, Jake.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Hello, Suzanne.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Vaughn?

Speaker: vaughn
Dialogue: I swear to God I didn't know who she was.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: You look beautiful.

Speaker: lynn
Dialogue: Thank you. I didn't think you'd come.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: I can't stay.  We gotta get to the park.

Speaker: lynn
Dialogue: Good luck today, Jake.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Yeh, you too.  Tell me one thing. The night you came up to my hotel -- was there really a library conference?

Speaker: lynn
Dialogue: No, I came to see you.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Too bad it didn't work out better. I just wanna say I'm sorry for all the things I've put you through over the years.

Speaker: lynn
Dialogue: Even for last night?

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Can't be sorry for that. Nothing happened.

Speaker: lynn
Dialogue: Then you weren't defending my honor again?

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: I didn't have to. She knew she was outclassed.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Come in.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Hello, Lou, what can I do for ya?

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: I wanted to hand in my resignation before you had a chance to fire me.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: What do you mean?

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: I know what you been tryin' to do with this team. After the season, I want no part of it.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Well, I knew I could count on Charlie to tell somebody. I was just afraid he might take too long.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Why would you want him to tell somebody?

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: So you'd tell the team, hopefully getting them mad enough to knock themselves out trying to prove they belonged in this league. I think it worked.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: You tryin' to make me believe you wanted us to win all along?

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Bullshit. What about the plane, the bus, the bad hotels...

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: We were broke. We couldn't afford anything better. Donald left the team nearly bankrupt. If we'd had another losing season, I would have had to sell the team. I knew we couldn't win with the team we had, so I decided to bring in new players and see how they'd do with the proper motivation. There was never any offer from Miami. I made it all up.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Why should I believe any of this? Now that we're winnin' it's easy for you to jump on the bandwagon.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: If I'd really wanted you to lose, all I had to do was send the best players back to the minors. But I didn't, did I?

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: You think this was all an accident? I personally scouted every member of this team, except Hayes, of course. He was a surprise. They all had flaws which concealed their real talent, or I wouldn't have been able to get them. But I knew if anyone could straighten them out, you could. And if you tell them any of this, I will fire you.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: I love this team, Lou. Go get 'em tonight.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: I don't know what Dorn's wife is up to, but I think it'd be best if you dressed early and got out to the bullpen before Dorn comes in.

Speaker: hayes
Dialogue: We got a problem. Cerrano wants some extra power for tonight. He's lookin' to sacrifice a live chicken. We can't have people pukin' in the locker room before the game.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Tell him not to worry, I'll take care of it.

Speaker: dorn
Dialogue: Bye bye, honey, wish me luck.

Speaker: suzanne
Dialogue: Before you go, there's something I wanta tell you.

Speaker: colorman
Dialogue: Here's your bourbon.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Won't need it tonight.

Speaker: dorn
Dialogue: You know where Vaughn is?

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Nope. Haven't seen him.

Speaker: dorn
Dialogue: Let me know if you do. I wanna have a little talk with him.

Speaker: cerrano
Dialogue: Where's my chicken?

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: It's comin' in now.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: One whole chicken, like you said.

Speaker: cerrano
Dialogue: But it no alive.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Believe me, Jo-Buu will like this. He's gotta be gettin' tired of raw chicken.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Hello, everybody, Harry Doyle bidding you a Wahoo welcome from beautiful Municipal Stadium, where tonight before a capacity crowd of 75,000 screaming featherheads, the braves of the Cuyahoga will leave their teepees in search of Cleveland's first League Championship in over 30 years. Standing in the way, their long time nemesis, the New York Yankees, the Big Boys of Broadway, who have beaten the Indians like a tom-tom all year long.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: All right, guys, let's take it to 'em.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Still nothing -- nothing, top of the seventh, two down. Harris has been in trouble all night, but has battled his way out with the help of some great defensive plays.

Speaker: rachel
Dialogue: Shit.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Damn, havin' trouble with the curve ball again.

Speaker: hayes
Dialogue: We should've gotten him a live chicken.

Speaker: cerrano
Dialogue: I pissed off now, Jo-Buu. I good to you, I stand up for you. If you no help me now, I say fuck you, Jo-Buu. I do it myself.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Long drive, deep centerfield. Way back. It might be. It could be. The ball is... Downtown, welcome to the Happy Hunting Ground. The game is tied.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Two down in the top of the ninth, still tied at 2, Harris working on an eight-hitter.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: You pitched a hell of a game, Steve. Take a seat and we'll see if we can get this guy for ya.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Give me Vaughn.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: You want Vaughn?

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: I know he hasn't done real well against this guy, but I got a hunch he's due.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Okay, Ricky, Haywood likes the hard stuff in. Curve him on the hands, bust him away, and don't get up with anything. You listenin' to me Rick?

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: O.K., kid, you're my man. Let's go get him.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: C'mon Ricky, this guy is the out you been waitin' your whole life for.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: O.K. Vaughn has finished his warmup and we're ready to...

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Oh, shit.

Speaker: dorn
Dialogue: Let's cut through the crap. I only got one thing to say to you. Just rear back and strike this motherfucker out.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: All right, Ricky, let's get nasty.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: All right, looks like the boy is pumped. Sucker was movin', wasn't it? Ever hit ya, it'd leave a two foot hole comin' out.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Let's see, what should we call now. Let's see how he feels about old number one.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Nice swing, Haywood. Good follow- through. Keep it up, I'll show you the ball sometime.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Forget the curveball. Go with the heater.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Well, shit, all these pitches to choose from. Maybe we'll try somethin' different this time.

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: And if I don't see you again, Haywood, have a nice winter. Okay, buddy?

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Can you believe this, Monty?

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Duke leads the league in saves, strikeouts per inning and nose hairs.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Ya know I'd be an ass not to pinch- hit for you here. You're 0 for 18 against Duke. Plus you're beat to shit you can hardly walk, there's no way you can get around on this guy's fast ball. So I want the absolute truth here. Can you beat this guy?

Speaker: taylor
Dialogue: Yeh.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Okay.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Send Hayes the first pitch. I don't want Taylor takin' too many strikes.

Speaker: pepper
Dialogue: What's he doing?

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Flashing some signals. That's a hell of an idea.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: ...Safe. The Indians win it. The Indians win. Oh my God, the Indians win it!!
